Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my heart thumping faster with every passing minute. As a delivery person, I knew how important it was to get this grocery order to Mrs. Lee before six—she’d called twice already, worried about her dinner plans. The address was just a few blocks away, but traffic was crawling, and I kept checking the insulated bag on the seat beside me, picturing her anxious face if I was late. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in fifteen minutes. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center tonight, and I could already imagine the line of people waiting outside, some of them elderly, all depending on me to open the doors and start the meal service. My mind raced, torn between the promise I’d made to a customer and the responsibility I felt toward the people at the center. Both needed me, both counted on me to be on time, and I felt the pressure of their expectations squeezing my chest as I sat at the red light, unable to move forward in either direction.
